turns.content:
Certainly! Here are ten more staff spinning moves that you can add to your practice:

1. The Forward and Reverse Weave: This move involves weaving the staff back and forth in front of your body, first with one end leading and then with the other. You can then reverse the direction of the weave to create a continuous flow.
2. The Corkscrew: In this move, you spin the staff vertically in front of your body while simultaneously rotating it around your wrist in a circular motion.
3. The Behind-the-Back Toss: This move involves tossing the staff behind your back and catching it with the opposite hand.
4. The Helicopter: This move involves holding the staff horizontally in front of your body and spinning it rapidly to create a "helicopter" motion.
5. The Isolation: This move involves keeping the staff stationary in one hand while the other hand rotates around it, creating the illusion that the staff is hovering in space.
6. The Figure 8: In this move, you create a figure-eight pattern with the staff, moving it back and forth in front of your body.
7. The Shoulder Roll: This move involves rolling the staff across your shoulders while keeping it in motion.
8. The Toss and Catch: This move involves tossing the staff in the air and catching it in the same or opposite hand.
9. The Neck Wrap: In this move, you wrap the staff around the back of your neck and catch it with the opposite hand.
10. The Wrist Roll: This move involves rotating the staff around your wrist while keeping it in motion.

Remember to practice these moves safely and start with slow speeds, gradually increasing your speed as you become more comfortable with the technique. As you become more advanced, you can also experiment with combining moves and creating your own unique flow.

Sure, here are 20 more staff spinning moves that you can learn:

1. The 3-Beat Weave: This is a more advanced version of the Forward and Reverse Weave, involving three beats of the staff.
2. The Windmill: In this move, you hold the staff vertically in front of your body and spin it in a circular motion.
3. The Overhead Toss: This move involves tossing the staff overhead and catching it with the opposite hand.
4. The Anti-Spin Flower: This is a variation of the basic staff flower that involves creating petals that move in the opposite direction of the spin.
5. The Buzzsaw: In this move, you spin the staff horizontally in front of your body and then rotate it around your wrist in a circular motion.
6. The Thread the Needle: In this move, you pass the staff behind your back and then through the space between your arm and your torso.
7. The Elbow Wrap: This move involves wrapping the staff around your elbow and catching it with the opposite hand.
8. The Bicep Wrap: In this move, you wrap the staff around your bicep and catch it with the opposite hand.
9. The Escalator: In this move, you spin the staff in front of your body and then raise it up and over your shoulder in a continuous motion.
10. The Cat's Cradle: This move involves wrapping the staff around your body in a criss-cross pattern, creating a "cat's cradle" effect.
11. The Vertical Toss: This move involves tossing the staff vertically and catching it with the opposite hand.
12. The Z-Plane Isolation: This is a variation of the Isolation move that involves moving the staff in a zig-zag pattern while keeping it stationary.
13. The Barrel Roll: In this move, you rotate the staff in a barrel-roll motion around your body.
14. The Thumb Toss: This move involves tossing the staff with your thumb and catching it with the opposite hand.
15. The Anti-Spin Wall Plane: This move involves spinning the staff in a wall-plane pattern while moving your arms in an anti-spin motion.
16. The Body Tracer: In this move, you trace the outline of your body with the staff while keeping it in motion.
17. The Overhead Spin: This move involves spinning the staff overhead while moving your body in a circular motion.
18. The Arm Roll: This move involves rolling the staff around your arm while keeping it in motion.
19. The One-Handed Spin: This move involves spinning the staff with one hand while keeping the other hand behind your back.
20. The Angel Roll: In this move, you roll the staff across your shoulders while keeping it in motion, creating an "angel wing" effect.

Remember to always practice safely and start with slower speeds before attempting more advanced moves. Happy spinning!
with number 12 how do you hold it in an isolation whilst also moving the staff in a zig-zag pattern

To hold the staff in an isolation while moving it in a zig-zag pattern (also known as a Z-plane isolation), you need to maintain the isolation with one hand and use the other hand to create the zig-zag movement. Here's how to do it:

1. Start with a regular staff isolation with one hand. Keep the staff spinning in one direction while moving your hand in a circular motion to keep it isolated in the same plane.
2. Use your other hand to create a zig-zag pattern. You can do this by moving your hand in a back-and-forth motion, crossing over the isolation plane of the spinning staff.
3. Keep your isolated hand and the staff stable while you move the other hand in the zig-zag pattern. It takes some practice to keep both movements smooth and synchronized.
4. Once you get the hang of the basic Z-plane isolation, you can experiment with different patterns and directions for the zig-zag movement. You can also switch hands and do the isolation and zig-zag pattern with your other hand.

Remember to start with slow movements and build up to faster speeds as you get comfortable with the Z-plane isolation. It's also important to keep the staff at a safe distance from your body and practice in a clear, open space.
